creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund; purchase from the collection of Elizabeth and Willard Clark
description: robed figure standing in center with large halo behind head, holding golden staff in PR hand and round black object in PL hand; figure stands on lotus riding on swirling clouds or waves
medium: Ink, color, and gold on silk
text: Though painted in the Edo period, the composition of this work is nearly identical to depictions of Jizō from centuries earlier due to the highly codified nature of Buddhist imagery. Here, Jizō descends from the heavens holding his usual accoutrements—a monk’s staff with six dangling rings and the ‘wish granting’ jewel—and wears the robes and shaved head of a monk. Sakai Hōitsu is best known for his decorative Rinpa works which covered birds and flowers, and subjects from classic literature, however, in 1798, Hōitsu became a lay monk, after which he produced a rash of Buddhist paintings.
title: Descent of Jizō Bosatsu
